description: Two majestic eleven-story twin towers built in 1953 opposite the train station, representing a vivid example of Stalinist classicism. These symmetrical towers combine elements of baroque, late classicism, and art deco, serving as the symbolic entrance to Minsk with one housing a century-old German clock trophy.
highlights: Built in 1953 in Stalinist Empire style
Designed by Leningrad architect Boris Rubanenko
3.5-meter German clock trophy from WWII on left tower
Coat of arms of former Belarusian SSR on right tower
3.5-meter tall sculptures of soldier, worker, collective farm girl, and engineer
Recently restored facades with new sculptures
Original spires and concrete pinnacles on upper tiers
tips: Best viewed from the square in front of train station
Evening visits recommended for beautiful illumination
Perfect photo opportunity - iconic Minsk landmark
Mechanical clock replaced with electronic but maintains original appearance
Consider joining sightseeing tour for historical context
vibe: Imposing, majestic, proudly Soviet - a grand architectural statement that announces your arrival in Minsk with unmistakable pomposity and historical gravitas
